newsitem.title: CANADA: Barrick says failed Bre-X offer fair.
newsitem.headline: Barrick says failed Bre-X offer fair.

text.p: Barrick Gold Corp said on Monday it told the Indonesian government that talks with Bre-X Minerals Ltd and the Indonesian partners did not yield a deal on the massive Busang gold deposit.

"We believe our proposal for Busang was fair and equitable to Bre-X and its partners, and provided for significant and social benefits for Indonesia," Barrick President and Chief Executive Officer Peter Munk said in a statement.
"We offered a very good economic deal for all concerned but to go beyond that in the circumstances would not have been in the best interests of our shareholders," he added.
Bre-X said earlier it, Freeport-McMoRan Copper & Gold Inc and Indonesian interests signed a Memorandum of Understanding for the development of Busang.
Bre-X said the venture will be 45 percent owned by Bre-X, 30 percent by two Indonesian companies and their partners, 10 percent by Indonesian government and 15 percent by Freeport McMoRan.
The Calgary-based company also announced in a separate statement that it had boosted its estimate of gold reserves at Busang by 13.6 million ounces to 70.95 million ounces.

"The future of this important national resource is in the hands of the Republic of Indonesia and we respect their right to decided what is in the best interests of the people of Indonesia. We remain committed to Indonesia and will continue to develop our promising exploration projects in this country," Munk added.
Barrick gold shares were down 1.95 at 34.00 soon after the opening in Toronto.
